paragraph: CHAPTER X. THE HOME OF HO-LOR.
tokens: chapter home

paragraph: “I LIVE over there,” said Ho-Lor with pride, pointing to the island with the pagoda on it. “Mi-Hy shall row us across, and Gra-Shus shall make us some tea.”
tokens: live say pride point island pagoda row make tea

paragraph: “Oh! yes,” said Gra-Shus clapping her hands. “And we’ll show Mr. Majesty Wallypug our beautiful pet dog—won’t we?”
tokens: say clap hand show beautiful pet dog

paragraph: It was impossible not to be interested in these quaint and simple-minded little folk, and after we had all stepped into the little boat and Mi-Hy had pushed off, his Majesty was soon chatting affably with Ho-Lor, who explained that he was a mandarin of the Blue Button, and ninety-eighth-cousin-twice-removed to the Emperor of China.
tokens: impossible interested quaint simple minded little folk step little boat push chat explain mandarin blue eighth cousin remove

paragraph: We soon reached the opposite bank, and his Majesty having been ceremoniously assisted out of the boat, we ascended a slight hill, and soon found ourselves before Ho-Lor’s residence. To our great surprise we found that it exactly resembled the building so familiar to all who have seen a willow-pattern plate.
tokens: reach opposite bank assist boat ascend slight hill find residence great surprise find resemble building familiar see willow pattern plate

paragraph: The tall pillars at the portico, the quaintly-shaped curly roofs, the little zig-zag fence running along the path, and the curious trees, all seemed to be old friends—while two little islands, one of which was connected to the mainland by a quaint bridge, completed the picture.
tokens: tall pillar portico shape curly roof little zig zag fence run path curious tree seem old friend little island connect mainland quaint bridge complete picture

paragraph: The two birds, which had by this time finished squabbling about the sandwich, were billing and cooing over our heads, and the sight of them seemed suddenly to convince us of the identity of the spot.
tokens: bird have time finish squabble sandwich billing cooe head sight seem convince identity spot

paragraph: “Why, this must be the land of the Willow-pattern plate,” cried his Majesty excitedly.
tokens: land pattern plate cry majesty

paragraph: “Yes, it is,” admitted Ho-Lor. “Don’t you think it is a very pretty spot?”
tokens: admit think pretty spot

paragraph: “Charming,” declared the Wallypug; “I have often wanted to come here.”
tokens: charming declare want come

paragraph: “The real name of the place,” said Ho-Lor, “is Wer-har-wei, and it is a portion of China; but come, you must see our little dog; I can hear that Mi-Hy has gone to fetch him.”
tokens: real name place say portion come see little dog hear go fetch

paragraph: “His name is Kis-Smee,” said Gra-Shus, “and he is such a dear old thing. We’ve had him ever since he was a puppy.”
tokens: name say dear old thing have puppy

paragraph: There was a sound of barking, and a confused clattering of chains, which told of a dog being unloosed. A moment afterwards there came bounding out of the house the most extraordinary-looking creature that I have ever beheld.
tokens: be sound barking confuse clattering chain tell dog unloose moment come bound house extraordinary look creature beheld

paragraph: It was a very fat and atrociously hideous animal, bearing but slight resemblance to a dog. Its enormous mouth wore a perpetual grin, and was decorated at the corners with curious little scallops. It was bandy-legged, and its hinder legs were much longer than the front ones. Added to this, the skin on its haunches was wrinkled up into curious kind of rosettes, while its tail was really all sorts of shapes.
tokens: fat hideous animal bear slight resemblance dog enormous mouth wear perpetual grin decorate corner curious little scallop bandy legged hinder leg long front one add skin haunch wrinkle curious kind rosette tail sort shape

paragraph: [“Come along, good dog! come and speak to the pretty Wallypugs.”—Page 119.   _Wallypugland._]
tokens: come good dog come speak pretty page

paragraph: This beautiful creature came careering down the steps, dragging Mi-Hy with him, and was hailed with delight by Gra-Shus, who cried in endearing tones:
tokens: beautiful creature come career step drag hail delight cry endearing tone

paragraph: “Come along, good dog! Come and speak to the pretty Wallypugs. Good Kis-Smee. Good dog, then!”
tokens: come good dog come speak pretty good good dog

paragraph: His Majesty clutched my arm nervously, and retreating behind the carpet-bag, regarded Kis-Smee with a certain amount of suspicion, while I must confess to having experienced a slight feeling of uneasiness myself. For if Kis-Smee took it into his ugly head to object to us, there was no knowing what might be the result.
tokens: clutch arm retreat carpet bag regard certain amount suspicion confess experience slight feeling uneasiness take ugly head object be know result

paragraph: There was no occasion for alarm, however, for Kis-Smee turned out to be one of the mildest and best-behaved of dogs.
tokens: be occasion alarm turn mildest behave dog

paragraph: He made great friends with the Wallypug at once, and clumsily gamboled, or, as his Majesty explained it, “flumped,” about him in the most friendly manner.
tokens: make great friend gambol explain flump friendly manner

paragraph: “He doesn’t take to strangers as a rule,” said Ho-Lor, “but he certainly seems to have taken a fancy to you.”
tokens: take stranger rule say seem take fancy

paragraph: “He is a beautiful creature,” said his Majesty, politely patting the huge animal a little nervously.
tokens: beautiful creature say pat huge animal little

paragraph: “Oh! I don’t know about that,” remarked Ho-Lor, looking very pleased nevertheless. “He is of a very rare breed, though.”
tokens: know remark look pleased rare breed

paragraph: “What kind of dog do you call him?” I inquired.
tokens: kind dog call inquire

paragraph: “He’s a smirkler dog,” replied Ho-Lor proudly.
tokens: smirkler dog reply

paragraph: “A what?” I exclaimed.
tokens: exclaim

paragraph: “A smirkler. He smirkles for mivlets you know,” was the reply.
tokens: smirkler smirkle mivlet know reply

paragraph: “Good gracious. What are they?” cried the Wallypug.
tokens: good gracious cry

paragraph: “Mivlets?” asked Ho-Lor.
tokens: mivlet ask

paragraph: [“HE IS A BEAUTIFUL CREATURE,” SAID HIS MAJESTY.]
tokens: beautiful creature say majesty

paragraph: His Majesty nodded.
tokens: nod

paragraph: “Why young mivs, of course.”
tokens: young miv course

paragraph: “But what are mivs?” asked his Majesty curiously.
tokens: miv ask

paragraph: “Things that are smirkled for,” replied Ho-Lor promptly. “But come. I see that Gra-Shus has prepared some tea for us.”
tokens: thing smirkle reply come see prepare tea

paragraph: We entered the little blue temple and were each presented with a little blue rug, upon which we sat cross-legged, as we observed that Mi-Hy and Ho-Lor were doing. Gra-Shus served us in blue cups what tasted like delicious tea, but which looked exactly like blue ink. No sooner had we taken a few sips than I noticed that the Wallypug was slowly turning a light blue color, while at the same moment he stared at me fixedly a moment, and then exclaimed: “Why, what a funny color you are!”
tokens: enter little blue temple present little blue rug sit cross-legged observe do serve blue cup taste delicious tea look blue ink take few sip notice turn light blue color same moment stare moment exclaim funny color

paragraph: I looked at my hands, and found them a rich blue shade.
tokens: look hand find rich blue shade

paragraph: “We look like the Oxford and Cambridge boat race, don’t we?” he continued: “I’m so glad that I’m Cambridge!”
tokens: look race continue glad

paragraph: I did not at all approve of the change, for although we did not look so very remarkable in the midst of our strange surroundings, I could not help thinking what an extraordinary object I should be considered in London if I ever reached that place again.
tokens: approve change look remarkable midst strange surroundings help think extraordinary object consider reach place

paragraph: “Oh! Aren’t they pretty now?” exclaimed Gra-Shus, clapping her hands and dancing about excitedly.
tokens: exclaim clap hand dance

paragraph: “I am glad you think so,” I replied, in a huff.
tokens: glad think reply huff

paragraph: “Don’t you like it? Would you rather have been green? We’ve plenty of green tea, you know, if you wish.”
tokens: like green plenty green tea know wish

paragraph: “Thanks! I should prefer being my original color, if you don’t mind,” I replied.
tokens: thanks prefer original color mind reply

paragraph: “Dear me! I’m very sorry, but I’m afraid we’re out of that color. Let’s see! Crushed strawberry, wasn’t it?”
tokens: sorry afraid color let see crush strawberry

paragraph: “Oh! let’s stay blue for a little while,” pleaded his Majesty. “It’s such a change, and so very uncommon, you know!”
tokens: let stay blue little while plead change uncommon know

paragraph: So blue we remained, and directly after we had finished our tea Mi-Hy brought around the little blue boat again, and we went for a row on the ornamental lake.

paragraph: Somehow or another Kis-Smee was left behind, and although the Wallypug suggested putting back for him, it was finally decided, however, not to do so.
tokens: leave suggest put decide do

paragraph: [WE WENT FOR A ROW ON THE ORNAMENTAL LAKE.]
tokens: went row ornamental

paragraph: “Perhaps he will smirkle a mivlet while we are away,” said Ho-Lor.
tokens: smirkle mivlet say

paragraph: And I confidently hoped that he might do so, for I was as curious as was the Wallypug to know what the term meant.
tokens: hope do curious know term mean

paragraph: Just then we passed a curious little blue island with one tiny house on it, standing in the midst of some curious trees and strangely-shaped rocks. “Let’s go ashore and fish,” suddenly suggested Mi-Hy.
tokens: pass curious little blue island tiny house stand midst curious tree shape rock let go fish suggest

paragraph: “Oh! yes, do,” cried the Wallypug. “I love fishing; but I’m never allowed to do so in my own land.”
tokens: do cry love fishing allow do own land

paragraph: “Why not?” inquired Ho-Lor.
tokens: inquire

paragraph: “The fishes object,” replied his Majesty, sadly; “they say that it gives them the tooth-ache.”
tokens: fish object reply say give tooth ache

paragraph: “How absurd of them,” said Ho-Lor, sympathetically.
tokens: absurd say

paragraph: “Yes; isn’t it perfectly ridiculous?” replied his Majesty; “for they really haven’t any teeth, you know.”
tokens: ridiculous reply have tooth know

paragraph: By this time the boat had reached the shore, and we all scrambled out and assisted Ho-Lor up the steep rocks.
tokens: time boat reach shore scramble assist steep rock

paragraph: From within the little blue house Mi-Hy brought some rods and lines, and we began to fish. There was no bait of any kind, but this Ho-Lor explained was not necessary.
tokens: little blue house bring rod line begin fish be bait kind explain necessary

paragraph: Under the circumstances I was not surprised to find that we did not get a bite for a considerable time.
tokens: circumstance surprised find get bite considerable time

paragraph: At last, however, the Wallypug announced with a delighted shout, “I’ve got one!” and we all ran over to see what it was.

paragraph: Slowly his Majesty wound up his line, while Mi-Hy hung over the rocks with a landing net. “I’ve got it!” he shouted. “Oh, what a beauty!” and diving his hand into the net, he drew out—what do you think? An empty ink-bottle!
tokens: wind line hang rock landing net get shout beauty diving hand net draw think empty ink bottle

paragraph: I couldn’t help laughing at his Majesty’s disappointed face, but Ho-Lor seemed positively to think that it was a catch worth having. “It’s in capital condition,” he exclaimed, examining it critically, “and has a beautifully-shaped neck.”
tokens: help laugh disappoint face seem think catch worth have capital condition exclaim examine have shape neck

paragraph: “But it’s only an old ink bottle,” objected the poor Wallypug.
tokens: old ink bottle object poor

paragraph: “What else did you expect to catch, I should like to know?” said Mi-Hy. “Some people are never satisfied. Many a time I have fished here a whole day and only caught a piece of blotting paper or a pen-wiper.”

paragraph: “What funny things to catch!” exclaimed the Wallypug.

paragraph: “They are very appropriate things to get from a lake of ink,” said Ho-Lor rather huffily.

paragraph: “Oh! I’m sure I beg your pardon, I had no idea it was real ink,” said his Majesty, apologetically. “I don’t think we had better fish any longer,” he said putting away his rod. “I hoped to have caught some real fish, you know.”

paragraph: We hurriedly launched the little boat, and were soon on our way across the little lake.

paragraph: The sound of furious barking, mingled with a strangely familiar voice, came from behind Ho-Lor’s house, and hurrying forward we came suddenly upon a remarkable sight.

paragraph: Kis-Smee was prancing madly round a gombobble tree to the lower branches of which A. Fish, Esq., was clinging in an agony of fright.

paragraph: [Kis-Smee was prancing madly round a gombobble tree to the lower branches of which A. Fish, Esq., was clinging in an agony of fright.—Page 128.   _Wallypugland._]

paragraph: Kis-Smee left his quarry in the tree, and came bounding up to the Wallypug, wagging his great clumsy tail delightedly.

paragraph: “Good gracious!” exclaimed Mi-Hy, staring in amazement at A. Fish, Esq. “That’s not a mivlet, I’m sure—what on earth is the creature?”
tokens: good gracious exclaim stare amazement mivlet sure earth creature

paragraph: “Oh, that’s A. Fish, Esq., a great friend of mine,” hastily explained his Majesty, running to his assistance, for when Kis-Smee had left him, poor A. Fish, Esq., had dropped off the gombobble tree, and was now lying exhausted on the blue grass beneath.
tokens: great friend explain run assistance leave poor drop gombobble tree lie exhaust blue grass

paragraph: “What a dreadful bodster!” he cried, waving Kis-Smee off as we approached. “Keep hib off. Take hib away!”
tokens: dreadful bodster cry wave approach keep hib take hib

paragraph: “It’s all right,” said his Majesty, reassuringly, “he won’t bite you now that we are here.”
tokens: right say bite

paragraph: Indeed, directly the dog discovered that A. Fish, Esq., was a friend of the Wallypug’s, he went up to him, and grinning in an absurd way, held out a paw to be shaken, which favor, however, was declined by A. Fish, Esq., who evidently regarded these overtures with a certain amount of suspicion, and looked greatly relieved when Ho-Lor and Mi-Hy, seeing that we were engaged with a friend, considerately left us to ourselves, and took Kis-Smee away with them.
